talk.author: did:plc:rzr3f4cafpsd6rrkroehs24w
talk.utter:
I had a friend who was testing positive intermittently for SIX WEEKS.

No chance of re-infection because he was isolating the whole time. Every time he'd think "okay, it's been a few days since my last positive test; maybe I can leave the house today" he'd test positive again.

talk.author: did:plc:77coz236u6px44bwz66sr6tq
talk.utter: That is not the correct way to use testing. False positives after infection are due to residual pieces of virus and he should not be considered positive. Days after symptom onset/resolution are used. This is a BIG DEAL. Why is this misinformation out there?!

talk.author: did:plc:rzr3f4cafpsd6rrkroehs24w
talk.utter:
I have actually read the literature on this topic, and it does not support what you are saying.

Can you cite a source for me, please?

talk.author: did:plc:rzr3f4cafpsd6rrkroehs24w
talk.utter:
I have actually read the literature on this topic, and it does not support what you are saying.

Can you cite a source for me, please?

talk.utter:

talk.utter:
For your perusal, I linked this li'l twitter lit review I did last spring elsethread: 

twitter.com/jakobpunkt/s...

talk.author: did:plc:77coz236u6px44bwz66sr6tq
talk.utter: But the days post infection also need to be considered - not just a blind correlation like these are doing! The CDC itself has put out info on this, but not sure it’s still accessible. I’ll look.

talk.author: did:plc:rzr3f4cafpsd6rrkroehs24w
talk.utter: The thing is, RATs just aren't very sensitive. I absolutely do not believe that there is sufficient "residual antigen" in someone's airway mucosa for days or weeks on end to show up as positive if it isn't being replenished by live, replicating virus.

talk.author: did:plc:rzr3f4cafpsd6rrkroehs24w
talk.utter: I think a reasonable argument could be made that there is live, replicating virus elsewhere in the body, whose corpses are being kicked out the nose by the immune system. But there is no way to test for that, so given a positive RAT, it is safest to assume you are infectious.
